description.text:
This fits into the slot in the base of a Dremel Workstation (220-01).
This might help stabilize a work piece. I upload this in the hopes it will give others ideas for similar accessories. Possible future improvements in future parts (room for others' innovation): a taper to make intital fit easier; a way to tighten it for extra stability; a part that grips while swiveling. The file format is brl-cad.
This has very tight tolerances and not all dremel bases have exactly the same dimensions, so you may need to file it a bit to make it fit.

description.text:
These are Walkera Rodeo F150 Feet/ landing gear with removable Propeller guards. The feet directly replace the original ones. The motor guards protect significantly more of the motor than the original ones. The additional prop guards are easily put on or taken off when you don't want to use them. These will protect your propellers and walls if you happen to run into something. These will push into the open hole in the feet and stay firmly in place. They can also be easily removed by pulling them out of the feet.
Enjoy!

title: Tejados modulares de tejas para Exin Castillos
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Grupo de archivos 3D para imprimir tejados modulares compatibles con Exin Castillos. Validos para tejados a dos y cuatro aguas...me quedan por subir algunas variantes.

Hay unas tejas especiales de remate para los contornos de los tejados. Esto es debido a que las tejas normales diseñadas tienen una altura de arranque de medio exinio (6,25mm) en lugar de la medida mas pequeña que tiene las tejas west y al ser mas altas en el frontal presentan un acabado mas basto. Con las de remate bajamos la altura del arranque de tejado a una medida esteticamente mas adecuada.

09/12/17 Actualizo archivos con subidas de nuevos modelos para haver mas versatiles los tejados: hay nuevas tejas de remate para facilitar tejados impares y tambien para tejado a 4 aguas con lados impares

03/01/18 Subidas cumbreras de ancho 3 exinios compatibles con tejados curvos

description.text: I recently took Skimbal's Thor's Hammer to MegaCon in Orlando, Florida, as a tribute to Stan Lee (who was in attendance). I wanted to make a smaller version that could be printed quickly for giveaways, and this is what I came up with. Note that I put both parts on the plate at the same time such that I could print a plate of silver and a plate of brown and then swap heads. My explanation -- the silver handle one is the "space version." They are rather cute, so no one minded that much. Next up: dualstrusion version of the same files!
Print two plates of these in separate colors (Silver and Brown being best choices), or export each part separately and merge as a dualstrusion print.

title: Prusa I3 Rework Bowden Carriage with Blower and Induction Sensor

description.text:
Continuing with my search for an even better extruder, Here's my new attempt that beats my previous one out of the water!

Improvements:

  • Replaced fans with Blower, this reduces the weight by replacing the mounts/screws/fans with a single blower.
  • Moved Inductive Sensor closer to the Hotend. This reduces the amount of bed space we loost on the previous version, and also gives more precise bed leveling data.

Printer:

Prusa I3 Rework

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

All parts printed in PLA. You can use ABS, but i haven't had any issues with heat.

BOM

Carriage Mount:
4 x (M4x20 Bolt)
4 x (M4 Nut)

Hotend Clamp:
2 x (M3x14 Bolt)
2 x (M3 Nut)

Fan:
4 x (M3x10 Bolt)

Blower:
1 x (M4x20 Bolt)
1 x (M4 Nut)

Blower Duct:
2 x (M3 x 10 Bolt)

Extruder:
Use the extruder from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1552129

Marlin Calibration

The offset from the Extruder Nozzle to the Induction Sensor is -29mm in the X axis.
#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -29

description.text:
Salut tout le monde! Je vous présente mon projet de console portable. Je me suis basé sur un Raspberry Pi 2B et pour la partie "autres composants" j'ai utilisé:

Pour l'alimentation:

  • 4 x Batteries 800mAh 3.7V
    https://www.amazon.fr/gp/product/B015FCPIBI/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
  • 1 x Carte PowerBoost 1000 Charger - Rechargeable 5V Lipo USB Boost @ 1A de Adafruit
    http://www.adafruit.com/products/2465#tutorials

Pour le son:

  • 1 x Carte Stereo 2.8W Class D Audio Amplifier - I2C Control AGC - TPA2016 de Adafruit
    http://www.adafruit.com/products/1712#tutorials
  • 2 X Mini Metal Speaker w/ Wires - 8 ohm 0.5W de Adafruit
    http://www.adafruit.com/products/1890#tutorials

Pour la vidéo:

  • 1 X Ecran PiTFT Plus 480x320 3.5" TFT+Touchscreen for Raspberry Pi de Adafruit
    http://www.adafruit.com/products/2441#tutorials

Pour la partie "manette":

  • 1 x Carte Teensy 3.2 de Adafruit
    http://www.adafruit.com/products/2756#tutorials
  • 2 x Joysticks PSP 2-Axis Analog Thumb Joystick
    http://www.adafruit.com/products/444#tutorials
  • 12 x Tactile Button switch (6mm) x 20 pack
    http://www.adafruit.com/products/367#tutorials

Pour l'architecture, la carte d'alimentation alimente directement le raspberry pi 2B et la carte son. Elle est assez puissante pour alimenter la console et en même temps recharger les batteries (pour ça il faut néanmoins un chargeur 2A). L'écran est connecté aux ports GPIO du Raspberry, je n'utilise pas la partie tactile de l'écran.
La carte son est connectée à deux hauts-parleurs et est reliée au Raspberry par la prise jack.
Pour la partie "manette", la carte teensy me permet de d'avoir une interface usb avec le raspberry pi et d'être reconnue par le Raspberry comme une manette classique usb du marché. J'ai écrit un programme qui prend en compte 12 boutons plus deux joysticks de PSP. (voir photos) Pour la partie "coque" je suis parti de 0 et j'ai conçu la console sur mesure sur FreeCAD.

Le tout fonctionne sous l'excellente distribution Recalbox:
http://www.recalbox.com.

description.text:
I got tired of listening to the loud cheap fan on the standard Chinese-made power supply that I use on many projects, so I made an adapter so I could use a near-silent magnetically suspended 120mm fan rather than the built in 60mm fan that comes with the unit. This did the trick. I used Blender to offset the small flange to near one of the corners so that, when installed, the fan is directly over the center of one end of the power supply instead of off to the side. Please note that technically this needs support when printed, but not practically. The small-end flange does get ugly when printed without support but it still does the job nicely when screws are put in from the metal side. The top of the flange is just fine and I'm not worried about the aesthetics of a power supply fan that I prefer to keep out of sight anyway. Printing with 4mm layers works just fine too. There is no need for fine detail so it is fine to go "quick and dirty".

If you like this and are feeling generous please consider feeding Foxpup. -> bitcoin:1KTAf3EM1kNWxpKrSSFqbESqYQZf2PAXdm Any amount, large or small, is appreciated, but only give if it brings you joy, not out of a sense of obligation. All the good ideas that Foxpup gets come from the Author of the universe and Foxpup is just passing them on :-)

A pivoting lifting device. The heavier the object it is lifting the greater the pressure holding it. Just tie a loop of rope or a chain to the top holes and lift away! Print two of everything and four each of both PinA and PinB. They just push together. You could use bolts instead of the pins as well. The foot needs support in the holes to print the inner wall flat. If the feet don't line up correctly then it is on backwards. The holes on the foot are closer to the edge on the ribbed side of the Lower Arm. Happy lifting!

author: pgelibrary

description.text:
My future son in law is working on his MA at the College Conservatory of Music at the University of Cincinnati. He is taking a conducting class and needed a baton. This baton is approximately 14 inches long and breaks down into three pieces. The sections are held together with 3mm machine screws. The handle has a hole in the base for a 3mm x 25mm screw, the two shaft pieces screw together with a 3mm x 40mm machine screw with the head cut off. I threaded the shaft pieces by slowly running in a 3mm machine screw with my small battery drill. Printing was done in
PLA using a raft with no support. The handle is printer standing up and the shaft pieces were printed lying horizontally, this gives then strength in the longitudinal axis.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm with a 0.40 nozzle

Timelapse of the print: https://youtu.be/j9YmPX3MW6w
Demo: https://youtu.be/5M077aAb-kE

I've sharpened a little the reed part with a knife, because it's really hard to print it thin enough.

Printer:

Prusa i3 Anet3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

My first project with a degree of absurdity, a full-scale Science Fiction inspired rifle. Designed from scratch and approximately the length of a Barrett M107. This is the longest (and largest) project I've ever attempted; the first model that took more more than 6 hours to design.
I had originally designed it to accept an HPA airsoft unit such as a wolverine SMP or a similar system, but some design quirks caused that attempt to end in failure. I'll probably re-attempt that when I get more time to tinker, but for now I figured it'd make a killer prop for anyone attempting a sci-fi costume or cosplay setup. Finished length is approximately 45 in, or 1.14 meters (it's pretty big).

This will take a couple spools of PLA if all parts are printed at 10-15% fill density. Many of the parts require a large amount of support material (the receiver pieces, magwell, and grip), so unfortunately there will be a lot of waste. The end result weighs around 1.1kg.
All pieces were sliced to fit a kossel mini's 180x180x230mm build area, so the unsliced full assembly files are included in case you wish to chop the model into larger pieces for printers with a larger work area. There is also an unsliced pistol version of this model, so you can slice and attempt that if a gigantic pistol works better for your costume than a rifle.

The Reflex sight model is an accessory sized to fit on the top rail, you can either leave it hollow or use the included template piece to cut out a piece of clear plastic to act as a lens, there is also room in the base to allow for some small electronics, along with a small hole to let the light from an LED shine onto the lens. So you should be able to cram a watch battery and an LED into position in the hollow base to make a functional dot sight.

Depending on the material you use you may need to adjust relative part scales (ie. 1.03 scale for the upper receiver, grip and handguard, 1.01 for the lower receiver, 0.99 for the magazine and pins, and sand/shave down parts that don't fit cleanly).

Assembly instructions: Print all parts out of PLA at 10-15% fill density, print the trigger in its two halves and glue them together, Print the stock recoil/butt pad out of TPU at a 30% fill density (or 10% density PLA, if you don't want the squish). There are two forms of the magazine, one extended and one standard length, and two forms of the magazine well (one branded with a radiation symbol on the left side, and the text "XR-11, cal. 0.230 SN#0001 on the right, and the other being plain, in case you want to do your own custom text or symbols).
After printing all parts, prepare the surfaces and adhere them using either superglue, gorilla glue (the "white" expanding type), or two-part epoxy. I personally used a glob of gorilla glue in the center of each piece, surrounded by dabs of superglue to make sure that everything held firm. The trigger is held in the body using a 1/8" pin (or a long m3 bolt), and there is room to add a spring inside the body if you want the trigger to function.
For body pins I've included a model file, but I would suggest printing it only as a size reference so you can pick up a pair of lynch pins from a hardware store, they'll be easier to insert and remove.

CostumeChallenge2017

print_settings.Printer:: Prusa i3 Pro B cheap China clone

title: Prusa i3 Pro B Z axis top brackets with blocks for strengthening rods

description.text:
The pertinax kind of material used for the frame of my i3 "Pro" B appears to be somewhat brittle, that the wish arose to fortify it. Because I had two 8mm spindles left - the result of replacing the Z spindles of this printer against trapezoid spindles - I used those, with two custom Z axis top brackets, modified with two blocks each to carry those rods.
Purpose of added rods is enabling the frame to carry heavy stuff, like filament reels, box feeders, tool trays, which I wouldn't trust my pertinax frame to carry without eventual breakage.

You can use these blocks with or without 608zz (8x22x7) ball bearings. If used without, the ball bearing insert offers a wide enough diameter to allow unrestricted wobble of the Z spindles, or indicate the necessity to align, straighten or replace the rods.

The photo still shows the previous version of these brackets. Later versions join the blocks for horizontal rods, for extra near rod support.

Goal of these brackets is to strengthen the top horizontal bar, not necessarily to introduce bearings. But before the endless pro/contra bearings discussion seems to get retriggered by the fact that I use these with bearings, I've added two photos: the G clamp (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1673030) has been printed without bearings, and shows the wavy pattern which I mentioned and added my thoughts about their origin in my reaction to a comment. The cylinder was printed with bearings. It (and other objects printed as far) don't display this wavy pattern, more clearly visible, by light reflection, in the photo which shows the G clamp alone. I'm sorry, I don't have identical items printed with and without bearings, for better comparison. My current opinion in the top bearing discussion: Don't restrict with wobbly spindles. Restrict with perfectly straight and aligned spindles. I'm likely and willing to change my opinion if new evidence supports it. For practical considerations, I opt for an agnostic position: any design which may be affected by it, will be able to operate either way.

.scad presets are suited for 5.5mm thick frame material. Customiser parametrisation still needs some work. If you're not ready to print and replace the top brackets, here's a stand-alone version of the blocks: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1789180

An early version of a top filament holder, which rests on the horizontal rods, has been published as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1801124

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 Pro B cheap China clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4mm nozzle, 0.3mm/layer

Infill:

12% 3dhoneycomb

Versions:

2016oct01: added strengthening rails along X axis. Meant to become rails for guiding the display, if mounted not centered, but moved to the side, the bridge between blocks obstructs a display at that position. Instead of weakening the bracket, by inserting a cut into the bridge, I accepted that display on that position and height is not recommandable. Instead, it could be moved up a bit, resting on the bridge.
Adjusted screw holes which weren't frame centered due to having introduced the variable "slack" for widening cutouts, but not considering that variable for hole positions.
Widened diameter for bearing recess

description.text:
basically, this is a printer that utilizes all the decent usable parts of the original PrintRite DIY 3d Printer (there aint many tbh) and puts them into a new frame (based loosely around the Prusa i3 design for added convenience) that actually looks good and works a WHOLE lot better while limiting cost to the absolute bare minimum.

AS SOMEONE RECENTLY ENQUIRED, YES THIS FRAME CAN BE USED WITH THE STOCK PRINTRITE MAINBOARD AND FIRMWARE, YOU NEED SIMPLY RETAIN THE ENTIRE STOCK Y-AXIS AS IS SO YOU STILL HAVE THE MAINBOARD MOUNTING POINT AND CONNECT THE Y-AXIS TO THE FRAME IN THE SAME WAY AS MY OWN VERSION IS CONNECTED, YOU DO NOT NEED TO SWITCH OUT TO RAMPS 1.4 TO USE THIS FRAME!, this might be beneficial to you for aslong as the stock PR board holds out... which tbh seems increasingly unlikely of late

ASSEMBLY INSTRUCTION PDF LINK:-
https://www.dropbox.com/s/yje18afhb1c6ca0/PolTur%20assembly%20instructions.pdf?dl=0

Printer:

Geeetech Prusa i3 pro B

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

If you have concerns that any of the parts may not be strong enough feel free to up the infill percentage, personally Ive had no real issue with 20% and the print time was obviously shorter.

just out of curiosity...

spent a little time looking into the cost of building this printer from absolute scratch (everything bought, nothing salvaged from another printer)

rough cost of buying all materials, electronics, motors, controller etc etc (everything needed to build a fully functional printer with the same specs as mine is around the £160 mark.

Im sure that cost would come down further if the builder spent a little more time sourcing parts from locations other than Ebay (which is all I used to get the rough price) and overseas suppliers (I only used UK suppliers for estimate)

some of the parts are hard to source, the 8mm smooth rods with threaded holes on their ends for example but with a little modification to the design of the printed parts (or even some light work with a files on the original designs) these could be substituted for 8mm threaded bar and nuts which is available everywhere.

hope that helps more.

House of Beauty is a cosmetics & accessories organizer.

By subtracting material out of a solid square box (12x12x12cm) I created holes/ cases for different kind of cosmetics & accessories, such as earings, brushes, eye shadows and pencils, rouges, lipsticks, mascaras etc.

Feel free to make use of the cases according your liking and your belongings.

Suggestions:
Front horizontal cases: eye shadows, rouge, powders.
Front small holes: earings
Right/ Left: lipsticks
Top deep: brushes, mascaras, pencils
Top shallow: other accessories
Back: bracelets, other accessories.

description.text:
This is a gopro 4 session case for Eachine racer 250.
it can hold the gopro in case of crash or heavy acceleration. (you can add rilsan to secure the gopro if you want but no need (I made a groove on purpose for this)
holes at the base matches those of the drone Eachine racer 250, you can screw it directly or attached it as you prefer.
the case is lightweight, you can have access to all the buttons of gopro 4 session, you can even have acces to the SD card and micro usb port
ABS and PLA prints work perfectly on my up mini (first version)
the the gopro angle is 25°.

yo!
This the revised version of my 3D-printed Lego, fixed from a failed Lego. This time, things turned out well. The holes can fit the Lego rod tightly, which means the they have impressive clutch power! The cross on both ends can fit the rod with raletivly small clutch power, but the rod can still stay in the cross.
In conclusion, the revised Lego is a success for me!

This is my first project after few weeks using Inventor. Since i'm still waiting for my printer i haven't tryed to print this yet so be ware that this might not fit. Idea of my initial came to my head when i realized that theres no space for screwholes unless wall thickness should be over sized so i went for letter M. Have fun!
Thanks.
I made this simply for practise sake as i learn using Inventor.

title: Main gear lever bottom bush (Land Rover SIII LHD)

description.text: After 6 months of getting a new main gear lever the rubber ring in the bottom decided to crack, tried to glue it without any success. Finally i've decided to print a ABS replacement part.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3 hephestos

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed @250ºC, and bed temperature 85ºC.

Requirements.

After printing and inserting it into place (it's a tight fit) the part needs to be "Glued" using acetone bath with the part assembled in its final position sitting around the lever rod.

a few seconds let it dry.

After that i've used a soldering iron to finish the surface matting.increasing the strength of the part.

comments.text: And? Does it hold up?
comments.author: RoGa

comments.text: So far it's holding, Just take the time to glue both parts with acetone and let it cure. other thing that i did was using a soldering iron on the joint's to weld them together, this will increase the part strength, and them used acetone to make it more soft.
comments.author: RoGa

description.text:
I struggled getting a decent, clean print with the original model, printing horizontal. Prints constantly failed and if it did succeed it looked like crap on the bottom. Printing vertical was an issue for me as well. So I ended up slicing the model in half to create a flat surface to build from. This allowed for beautiful print lines and no need for support.

After printing, especially if you don't have a glass print bed, take some time to sand the flat sides of the halves. Afterwards they are ready to be glued together with epoxy or super glue.

I spent some time finishing my wand by sanding, priming, and painting it. People love the look, give it a try! I hope this helps those others out there that faced similar issues.

Feel free to leave a tip. They are greatly appreciated and helps produce more wonderful content!

Printer:

XYZPrinting Da Vinci Pro

No

No

50%

I wanted the wand to have a realistic feel of weight so I up the infill to 50%. Although it will print fine with 20+.

A Cookie Cutter for XMas Cookies, in germany we call them "Spitzbuben": 300g /10.5 oz plain flour
2 tsp baking powder
100g / 3.5 oz sugar
1 pk / 1/4 oz Vanilla sugar
1 eggs
150g / 6 oz butter, unsalted
20g / 1 oz powdered sugar
40g / 1.5 oz red currant jelly In a bowl mix flour, baking powder, sugar and vanilla sugar together. Add 1 egg and very cold, unsalted butter in small pieces. Quickly bring everything together to form a soft dough. You don't need to refrigerate the dough. Roll out the half of the dough on a floured workspace. With a cookie cutter cut out 25 big hearts. Put them on a parchment paper lined baking tray. Do the same with the other half of the dough. But additionally cut out small hearts from the middle of 25 hearts. Pre heat the oven to 160 C / 320 F. Bake the Spitzbuben for about 8-9 minutes until lightly brown. Let them cool down on the baking tray to become firm and crispy. Dust all cookies with confectioner's sugar. Put a small amount of red currant jelly on all whole cookies and top with a cookie with a hole in the middle. After the jelly is dry, store them in a tin can. Be happy! Omnomnomnom

title: Prusa i3v Bed Cable Chain Ends (Updated Oct 4th)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Download the "CableChain.stl" file from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11978/#files

Use as many Cable Chain segments as you need for your bed movement, use these End Segments to create a Cable Chain perfect for your Prusa i3v Heated Bed! This design doesn't compromise the structure of the forward laser cut wood panel but does require a cutout of the rear panel.

Wires from your power supply and RAMPS board pass through this cable chain to the heated bed to ensure they don't get caught on the moving bed.

Changelog:
Oct 4th Update: I created a bracket for the rear of the bed so the wires won't get caught between the moving bed and the stepper motor at the back. Zip-ties hold the wires in place along the bracket and into the cable chain. It works really well!

Sept 27th Update: I removed the remaining side mounting holes on the Male and Female ends (improves print quality of female button holes). Also separated the pieces into individual STLs to better arrange them for printing. Installed the parts on my printer at home and uploaded photos.

https://youtu.be/fByQV3NKrpw
https://youtu.be/xThgSBHNt3s

description.text:
This is a mount for the resqme® Car Escape Tool. It allows you to place the tool in an easy-to-reach location while keeping it out of the way. This also prevents it from getting jumbled in with all of the everyday clutter that tends to fill up spaces such as glove boxes and center consoles making it easier to find in an emergency.

I found that the perfect spot for mine is under the lid of my center console but you may find a better spot. The key is to put it somewhere within arms reach so that in case of an emergency it is easily accessible.

Attaches easily with a small adhesive strip or double-sided tape. If you choose to go with tape, I recommend using some with a foam core to allow for the slight flexing that occurs when the tool is inserted into the holder. You wouldn't want it to pop off and get lost at an inopportune moment!

Be sure to either purchase a brightly colored tool or print the holder in a bright color for maximum visibility.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

Easy, quick print. I went with 100% infill but you could probably get away with less. Truth be told the part is so thin that you'll barely have any infill areas so that setting doesn't really matter.

Your party has been traversing a dank, slimy dungeon for what feels like weeks. The dim flicker of a torch is the only light for which to see. You notice a gated opening at the end of a hall, but a shadowy mass seems to block the way. The mage cast a prismatic orb that shoots quickly down the hall illuminating a massive glazed over eye floating just in front of the gate. As quick as the orb of light appears, it is extinguished as another eye emits a bright pale pulse, which collides with the orb. A horrifying shriek echos from that same floating eye. The Beholder is awake.....and very angry.

Roll for initiative.

print_settings.Notes:: Flowers do not need supports or rafts, but be sure to print 3 copies.

description.text:
This handy little hummingbird feeder can be stuck on the outside of an exterior window with a small suction cup. Great for watching hummingbirds from the comfort of your couch inside.

Unlike some other printable hummingbird feeders, this one includes all parts needed for a functional feeder, even the bottle. The bottle screws onto the base and is able to freely rotate with respect to the base to ensure that the feeder is flush against the window. The flowers, lid, and base all snap together with no glue or fasteners needed.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Bottle should be printed standing upright with the screw-threaded portion at the base to ensure that the threaded piece is able to rotate around the bottle. This may require using a raft to ensure the bottle does not fall over during printing. Bottle should be printed with NO supports.

Base is printed with no supports or raft.

Lid should be printed with supports, but no raft.

Flowers do not need supports or rafts, but be sure to print 3 copies.

description.text:
Tired of boring old 3D? Wanna spice things up with yet another dimension or so? Well, look no further, friend! Here's the first-ever 3D printed 3D-stereoscopic postcard! Yeah... you get the idea. Just print it out, put it in your trusty ol' stereoscope and voila! A 3D experience that, um, is nothing short of... fascinating, actually. It is interesting to see a 3D image comprised of 3D materials, arranged in a stereoscopic manner. Give it a try.

Dimensions are 3.5" x 5" (or 88.9mm x 127mm). This assumes an inter-pupillary distance of 63.5mm. Since this thing is so flat and thin, you may consider using Glide dental floss to remove it from your printing plate. It works quite well on my stock Flashforge heated build plate surface.

What? No stereoscope? Your 3D printer can fix that:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1108267

If you found this useful, please share your work and be sure to peruse my other submissions which are almost as varied as they are many:

http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

Enjoy!

description.text:
Included is the 3d model output from my slicing software, as well as several source files from which I generated it.

This is a VERY rough initial model that I'm working on for a siyah (rigid end of a limb) for a Turkish-style bow. I make bows out of PVC, and usually carve the siyahs out of wood - but printing them could be much faster, not to mention lighter, stronger (nylon sounds great!), and more customizable.

PLEASE remix this! I think I have it sized right - to about 3.1-3.2 inches long from the middle of the radius to the tip. I'm still trying to figure out how to taper the bottom half to a point, and how to give the bash, the end with the nock, a rounded-triangular cross-section (pinched at the back, basically).

I'm going to print a few of these out and give it a shot in a PVC bow, so wish me luck!

Google sketchup - I traced an image I created (if anyone really wants it, I'll share it), then extruded it to a width of 1/2". That may or may not be perfect, but it's close enough, and a good place to start.

title: Roger B. Taney Bust - Frederick, Maryland

description.text:
Roger Brooke Taney was fifth Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court. Nominated to the court by Andrew Jackson, Taney is best known for his decision in Dred Scott v. Sandford. In the decision, Taney held that African-Americans in America could not be citizens:

"They had for more than a century before been regarded as beings of an inferior order, and altogether unfit to associate with the white race, either in social or political relations; and so far inferior, that they had no rights which the white man was bound to respect; and that the negro might justly and lawfully be reduced to slavery for his benefit."

Taney practiced law between 1801 and 1823 in Frederick, Maryland, owning property in the city and serving as chair of many local institutions. In 1931, the bust was placed in front of the then-Frederick County courthouse. Frederick City officials have recently moved to remove the pro-slavery lawyer and judge's bust.

description.text:
We used to keep our kitchen scrubber in a shallow dish next to the sink. My wife didn't like how it could sit in a little puddle of water if it hadn't been wrung out thoroughly, so she swapped out the dish for a binder clip. I absolutely despise the binder clip. It worked great for standing up the scrubber and letting water drain out of it, but it was a pain to put on and I was just opposed to the general idea of a binder clip as a sponge holder.

Printer to the rescue! This little dish sets the kitchen scrubber above the bottom of the dish so water can drop down into the tray, letting the scrubber dry and avoid growing nasty bacteria. If there's considerable drippage, the honeycomb patterned shelf lifts off and the tray can be poured out and/or cleaned.

This may serve well as a soap tray, too. Let your domestic imagination run wild and be sure to share by posting your make.

author: toto2003

description.text:
This is a microphone jack for a general aviation headset. The socket is designed for use with a jumbo paperclip (1mm diameter). This design has only common and mic. I did not include a location for a PTT connector, but it would be easy for anyone to modify the file to include that.

This was created in order to connect a headset to an FT-897D radio. The circuit here worked quite well: http://www.dj2um.com/2012/04/15/aviation-headset-interface-ft897/

Assembly requires glue (preferably something strong like epoxy), a single jumbo paperclip, 2 wires, a wire cutter capable of cutting the paperclip, a soldering iron, solder, and a pair of small pliers. A drill bit will probably be required unless your printer makes perfect holes.

Step 1

Drill out the center hole for the connector with a .206" or slightly larger drill bit. I used a number 4 drill bit, size .209" and this worked perfectly. If your print comes out with a perfectly sized hole to begin with, this step will be unnecessary.

Step 2

Cut an inch or 2 of straight metal from the paperclip. Insert it through the hole on the circumference of the socket that has the INTERNAL GROOVE, not the external groove. Insert the paperclip far enough that it almost, but does not, enter the opposite hole. The paperclip should be obstructing the large center hole of the jack where the male connector passes through. Then, push the male PJ-068 plug through the hole. This will bend the paperclip so that it rests in the internal groove. Trim the excess as desired, making sure to leave enough so that a wire can be soldered on to it.

Step 3

Cut another inch or two of straight paperclip. Bend it as shown in the picture. This will require trial and error. It should be approximately touching the mic connector of the male plug, but a final adjustment will be required after the socket is glued together so this step does not require precision.

Step 4

Solder wires to the paperclip. Do this before gluing. If possible, use a small clamp or soldering heatsink to draw heat away and keep the plastic from melting.

Step 5

Glue the common paperclip in place (the one resting in the internal groove). You will want the glue to fill up the small hole the paperclip passes through, but you do not want any glue on the interior of the large center hole or inside the groove. This is so that you can slightly bend the paperclip inwards for a solid contact with the male plug after the glue is set.

Step 6

Apply glue and place the mic contact paperclip connector in position, then apply the external ring (with additional glue) for reinforcement.

Step 7

After the glue has cured to full strength (typically 24 hours for epoxy) bend the paperclip that should contact the mic portion of the male connector into the correct position. Bend the paperclip that should contact the common portion of the male connector slightly inwards towards the middle of the large center hole so that it makes a good connection.

The little square column in the center places pressure on the board to keep it from moving without adding additional hardware. This was for a current sensing project i did, the Green LED comes on when a certain amount of current passes through the sensor and it signals my home automation system.

author: nanpawang

description.text:
Materials and sources to buy them:
1 latching click button
https://www.amazon.com/uxcell%C2%AE-Horizontal-Latching-Button-Switch/dp/B0094FGKN8/ref=pd_sim_60_16?ie=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=GY3K3B75NJCNCWWV7WFB

DC motor https://www.amazon.com/130-16140-12500RPM-Motor-Varistor-Smart/dp/B00JR6IY4M/ref=sr_1_10?ie=UTF8&qid=1474940305&sr=8-10&keywords=electric%2Bmotor

Super glue

USB charger of any kind (iphone, micro USB, etc.)

Hot Glue Gun

Instructions:

  1. Take your charger, and cut the tip off, you should find a black and red wire, skin the insulation off of the tips of the two wires.

  2. Take your motor, and place it inside of the small space designed to fit it, it should be stuck once inside.

  3. Take your latching button, and twist, hot glue, or solder your wire to one of the metal prongs on the button, take another small piece of wire, and on the other prong do the same.

  4. Take your black wire, and hot glue it onto the left tiny prong of the motor, hot glue your red wire to the right little prong.

  5. Super Glue your fan blade onto the turning prong on the front and middle part of the motor.

  6. Either super glue, or plastic weld all parts together as seen in picture or video.
  7. You're done! Plug the USB in and turn the fan on!

FYI:
The fan does rattle A LOT, so keep it on a mouse pad. Unfortunately I was not able to upload my video to YouTube(I have super slow internet) however the fan does work very nice!

Please upload your makes! I would love to see other people make this!

author: opensourcebear

description.text: STL A

Tired of tightening the short timing belts so often? Here's the snap-on floating belt tensioner.  
The tightener can move freely along the belt. Flanges on the roller parts keep the assembly from falling off. Attach small pieces of felt to the faces touching the steppers or the walls if you encounter rattling or rasping noises.

Print at 0.1mm layer height, 1.2mm wall thickness and 20% infill. Clean bores after printing to let the sliders move smoothly along the guide bar screws. Tighten the roller screws to a loose fit to let the ball bearings move freely. Check for smooth-running of rollers and sliders before attaching the tighteners to the belts. Snap on the belt tighteners onto the short belts and make sure the flanges are embracing the belts at the side facing the walls. If the belt is too close to the wall, re-adjust the pulleys to have 1-2mm clearance from the walls. The rollers should barely touch the walls but not scratch them. Bill of materials: 2 slider (printed part)
2 roller (printed part)
2 ball bearings 10x6x3
2 screws M3x30
2 screws M3x16
2 nuts M3
2 nuts M3 self-locking or M3 + Loctite
1 tension spring 10mm (not too strong...) Hint:
Save the nuts and glue the guide bar screws into one slider part. Update:
Minor changes to roller part. Flages extended to prevent tensioner occasionally falling off. Larger bore for screw head to fit an additional washer for reduced friction between the roller and the screw.

comments.text: Unfortunately, while an great design, you never want to introduce a spring into belt tension in a linear motion system. All a spring does is increase ringing and overshoot effects. The ONLY way to properly tension belts in this system is fixed tensioner methods.
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: Thanks for your comment. I generally agree, but I think your concerns do not apply here. The sprung system is not supported by the non-moving frame, that's the small but nice trick of this design. Directional changes of the belt movement will not cause the spring to be deflected and store/release energy. If one piece of the belt is tightening, the opposite part will loose the same way, so the tensioner assembly will slightly move laterally, but the spring will not see any deflection. There is no dynamics in the tensioner length at all, the spring just applies "static" stress to both belt parts symmetrically. Fixing one part of the tensioner body to the frame indeed would introduce the problems you mentioned.
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: Very clever.  Tensioning these belts by deflecting them perpendicular to their length makes really good sense, because you have such better fine control.  With other methods that tension by lengthening the belt by pulling the NEMA down are much less precise, because a tiny change in length will have a large effect on tension.  This also keeps consistent tension regardless of thermal-induced length changes.
comments.author: skovgaar

description.text:
(Note this is a redesign to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1713141 - it is more compact and far more effective)
Attached STL's are junction fittings used in the construction of a 38cm diam H Field loop antenna as part of a lightning detection system (see http://en.blitzortung.org ). The 2 junction fittings secure in the 1/4" Copper tube loops (6mm) and also house the ferrite toroid Transformer. The plastic tube between the top & bottom mount is just electical PVC conduit.
The 2 loops are offset vertically from each other so they are electically isolated

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Mendel 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm 1st layer then 0.3mm using slic3r

Infill:

hex @ 50%

Notes:

I used PLA. ABS might be better. As it will be out in the weather the parts should be painted to slow down degradation.

The holes for the tube to pass through are angled (for the loop) and may need to be reemed out with a suitable size drill.

The Copper loops are formed 1st in the 38cm Diam circle (but do not join the circle ends until fully assembled into top & bottom fitting).

The Copper loops are carefully slid through both housings (and also the wound toroid inside the bottom housing). The PVC conduit should be cut to length after putting both tubes into the fittings.

Final step is to solder the tubes together, a small piece of brass or copper tube as an internal sleeve at the joint will assist the solder jointing. It is important that the tube is electrically joined as the H fields from lightning need to induce a current in the loop (which in turn is coupled into the ferrite toroid windings)

comments.text: What torroids did you use for the design? I'm presuming the copper is a continuous loop
comments.author: tkerby

comments.text: I used 25mm ferrites (OD=25mm ID=15mm) that were avaialble at the local electronics shop ( https://www.jaycar.com.au/l8-25x15x10mm-toroid-or-ring-cores-pk-4/p/LO1234 ). specs of the ferrite are a little hard to find but I tried it and it seemed to work (other designs have used a TDK N30 ferrite material). I used 1mm enameled Cu wire for the winding (50 turns) which made it a fairly snug fit over the 7mm copper tube. The copper tube is continuous - splice soldered after assembly (but not touching the other tube). A thinner wire would have been an easier fit.
comments.author: tkerby

title: Slim Rostock Max V3 part fan shroud

description.text:
This mod moves the three part fans on the HE280 in and up above the hot end. The point of this mod is to allow a narrow enclosure. The stock part fan layout moves the fans considerably outside the base frame when the head is near the bed limits. This allows full travel with a narrow enclosure.

Airflow is a bit less, but better directed. You still will not need to run the fans at 100% in my experience.

You will need to trim the small plastic tabs on the effector plate before installing the shrouds.

Print 3

It is always a pain finding a good heat dissipating laptop stand for use on the desktop. Commercial laptop stand usually come with a fan beneath which is fail prone and noisy. description.text: This is my model of the Mar's Spaceship from the Invader Zim episode, Battle of the Planets. I did this model myself, so don't take credit for my creation.

Based on the MakerBolt by Aubenc, but without the original sizing, thread length, or "M" on the head.  Instead these are more finger friendly with the hexagonal shape and slightly longer thread length.  
I designed these with kids in mind, and I included a blank bolt so that you can easily toss on your own emboss pattern.

print_settings.Notes:: Printing the main parts together helps improve the detail of the center piece. Also the disks and spacers are printed at 100% infill. Please feel free to ask any questions.

description.text: This is my interpretation of the Arc Reactor from "Iron Man". I strayed far from the actual arc reactor but decided to use it for inspiration instead. There are 3 main body parts, a connector, 6 disks that make up a heat-sink and 6 spacers. This design requires NO support material and minimal sanding on the connector and center piece in order to create a snug fit. No glue is necessary. This design was created with 3D printing in mind.

title: Eachine 700TVL 2.8mm 35deg mount for a RotorX Atom

description.text:
Been a while since I've put anything up. It's not much but I've got more coming once I've got the time. Just recently put my Atom back together with a Piko BLX FC and a Innova VTX from Furious FPV. Here's the untuned maiden if your curious https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jLZmBPkstLQ
I should have the mount I made for that FC that fits the Atom up shortly after I make some final adjustments to it. It fits a Eachine 700tvl or anything else with a similar size lens. Basically 8.5mm diameter behind the lens baffle. if this helps here's where I got mine https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0148HVZIQ/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1.
Print in TPU
Install your camera by unthreading the lens and threading it back in through the mount.
As always let me know if there's any adjustments I could make to fit your camera's dimensions.
Thanks and Enjoy
